newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dollar/yen vols stay offered after G7.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dollar/yen vols stay offered after G7.

text.p: Implied volatilities for front-end dollar/yen options stayed offered Monday afternoon in dull trade but had stabilized after selling off from last week's peaks hit before the uneventful Group of Seven summit.
"People are long vol and they've definitely just unloaded a lot of it. It's just vol is offered," said one options broker. "But people are just sitting around. Nothing's going through."
Dollar/yen by 1515 CDT/2015 GMT had pierced 115.00 and hit day's low at 114.60, well off its overnight peak near 115.60, which was just shy of trendline resistance near 115.75.
At late afternoon Monday, one-month dollar/yen was quoted at 10.15/10.45 percent versus 10.0/10.4 at Europe's morning and off sharply from 10.8/11.0 percent Friday early afternoon.

By late Friday, vols already had begun skidding from peaks as players revised expectations of the G7 summit and decided -- correctly -- that it would not have earth-shattering effect on spot, said Alan Revercomb, options strategist, IDEA Inc.
"Vols have eroded," he said. "So as long as we are kind of orbiting 115, it's certainly not going to set fear into anyone. If we get above 116-117, you may sort of turn things around."

On Monday afternoon, the one-month, 25-delta risk-reversal still strongly favored yen calls but by a much smaller margin than last week, brokers said. The demand gauge for puts and calls was quoted at roughly 1.7/2.1 points, little changed from earlier in the day and off from 2.2/2.4 Friday afternoon.

"You still have a risk reversal that's skewed sharply to the (dollar's) downside. There's still a lot of positions on, and there's still demand for those downside strikes," said Revercomb. "So I don't think the market has given up, but you may have had too many people jumping the gun last week...so you have a lot of people positioned the same way."
But brokers were unsure whether the market already had factored in the Bank of Japan's Tankan report Wednesday.
"I think it's (Tankan) all priced in, but I just think nobody's interested in doing anything," said the broker.
"You've got Tankan...so there's definitely going to be a floor under volatilities," said Revercomb, who called 10.0 percent in dollar/yen "a reasonable floor."
"But if we spend more than couple days here around 115, then there'll be another round of selling," he added. "If spot gets under 115, you're not going to see vols come off much."

In dollar/mark, the one-month 25-delta vol stayed stuck late Monday near 8.20/8.50 percent, off slightly from the 8.30/8.60 percent quoted in Europe earlier Monday and compared to 8.40/8.70 percent seen Friday afternoon. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750)) E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com
